results.name: Unique triangle such that (1) every positive integer occurs exactly once; (2) row n consists of n consecutive numbers; (3) odd-numbered rows are decreasing; (4) even-numbered rows are increasing; and (5) column 1 is increasing.
comment: Self-inverse permutation of the natural numbers.
Mirror image of triangle in A056011. - _Philippe Deléham_, Apr 04 2009
When formatted as a rectangle R, for m > 1, the numbers n-1 and n+1 are neighbors (row, column, or diagonal) of R.
R(n,k) = n + (k+n-2)(k+n-1)/2 if n+k is odd;
R(n,k) = k + (n+k-2)(n+k-1)/2 if n+k is even.
a(n) is a pairing function: a function that reversibly maps Z^{+} x Z^{+} onto Z^{+}, where Z^{+} is the set of integer positive numbers. - _Boris Putievskiy_, Dec 24 2012
For generalizations see A218890, A213927. - _Boris Putievskiy_, Mar 10 2013
link: Ivan Neretin, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..5050
Boris Putievskiy, Transformations Integer Sequences And Pairing Functions arXiv:1212.2732 [math.CO], 2012.
Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
formula: T(n, k) = (n^2 - (n - 2*k)*(-1)^(n mod 2))/2 + n mod 2. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Apr 25 2004
example: Enumeration by boustrophedonic ("ox-plowing") diagonal method. - _Boris Putievskiy_, Dec 24 2012
